The Cabinet had before them a Memorandximby the First Lord of the Admiralty (Paper CP.-239 (27)) proposing the withdrawal of the FirstCruiser Squadron of five ships.The First Lord of the Admiralty informed the Cabinet that, owing to the low river season(November to april), Cruisers could not be usedon the Yangtse and the Naval commonwealth-ander-in-Chiefwas agreeable to release the ships, which could proceed again to the East if the situation inChina should render it necessary. Mr Bridgemanrecalled that the ships had been sent out inorder to bring rapidly to China a motile landing,party for use in emergency, since when largemilitary reinforcements had arrived. TheAdmiralty had already withdrawn 500 Marinesamd hoped in the near future to withdraw theremaining 500, but, if necessary, they wouldrather retain 500 Marines than keep the FirstCruiser Squadron in the Far East.The Cabinet agreed (a) That the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs should send atelegram to the British minister in Peking to the effect that he presumed that the Naval commander-in-Chief had kept the British-Minister informed as to what was proposed, and that he confirmed the Commander-in-chief's view.He should add that His Majesty'sGovernment proposed to sanction the withdrawal:(b) That, pending the receipt of a reply from Sir Miles Lampson, no announcement should be made in thePress as to the withdrawal of theFirst Cruiser Squadron.
